title: Final Review & Exam Readiness
description: Comprehensive AP exam-format review synthesizing all 10 units. Mixed-topic problem sets practicing MC strategies (no-calculator and calculator), FRQ justification writing, and error analysis. Designed to simulate real AP exam conditions and identify remaining gaps before the final assessment.
standardsAlignment: AP Calculus BC CED 2020 — All Learning Objectives
goals: Synthesize derivative and integral techniques across all function types.
Apply convergence tests fluently and select Taylor/Maclaurin series for approximation.
Write AP-quality justifications for FRQs: state conditions, cite theorems, use correct notation.
Manage time effectively across MC and FRQ sections under exam conditions.
instructionalStrategy: AI-led diagnostic review targeting weakest areas first
Mixed-topic problem sets to build fluency switching between units
Timed practice sections simulating AP exam pressure
Error categorization: conceptual vs computational vs notational

scaffold.title: Review Block A: Limits, Derivatives & Their Applications (Units 1–5)
scaffold.content: Comprehensive review of the derivative half of AP Calculus BC.
keyPoints: Limits: algebraic manipulation (factor, conjugate, common denominator), L'Hôpital (0/0 or ∞/∞ ONLY), limits at infinity, squeeze theorem.
Continuity: three conditions (exists, defined, equal); IVT requires continuity on closed interval.
Derivative definition: lim_{h→0}[f(x+h)−f(x)]/h and alternate form lim_{x→a}[f(x)−f(a)]/(x−a).
Differentiation rules: power, product, quotient, chain (including nested), implicit, inverse function (1/f'(f⁻¹(a))), inverse trig.
Applications: related rates (always differentiate BEFORE substituting), motion (v=s', a=v', speed=|v|), linearization L(x)=f(a)+f'(a)(x−a).
Function analysis: FDT/SDT, concavity, inflection points, EVT (check endpoints + critical), MVT (f'(c)=[f(b)−f(a)]/(b−a)), optimization.

scaffold.title: Review Block A: Mixed Derivative Problems

problems.question: Evaluate lim_{x→0} (tan(2x))/(3x). State the method used.
hints: Check the form first — is it 0/0 or ∞/∞?
You could also rewrite tan as sin/cos and use the standard limit sin(u)/u → 1.

problems.question: Given f(x) = x·e^(−2x), find the absolute maximum on [0, ∞).
hints: Use product rule for x·e^(−2x).
Don't forget to check the behavior as x→∞.

problems.question: A 10-cm wire is cut into two pieces. One forms a square, the other an equilateral triangle. Where should the cut be to minimize total area?
hints: Set up area as a function of one variable (the cut point).
Differentiate and set equal to zero.

scaffold.title: Review Block B: Integration, Differential Equations & Applications (Units 6–8)
scaffold.content: Comprehensive review of integration and its applications.
keyPoints: Riemann sums: left, right, midpoint, trapezoidal; over/underestimate depends on monotonicity and concavity.
FTC Part 1: d/dx∫ₐˣf(t)dt = f(x); with chain rule: d/dx∫ₐ^{g(x)}f(t)dt = f(g(x))·g'(x).
FTC Part 2: ∫ₐᵇf(x)dx = F(b)−F(a) where F'=f.

Techniques: u-substitution (change bounds for definite), integration by parts (∫udv=uv−∫vdu; LIATE priority), partial fractions (factor denominator, A/(x−r)+B/(x−s)), improper integrals (replace bound with limit).

Differential equations: slope fields (match dy/dx to slopes), separation of variables (separate, integrate, +C, apply IC), Euler's method (y_{n+1}=yₙ+f(xₙ,yₙ)Δx), logistic (dP/dt=kP(1−P/L), max rate at P=L/2).
Applications: area between curves (∫[top−bottom]dx), volume (disk π∫R²dx, washer π∫(R²−r²)dx, cross-section ∫A(x)dx), average value (1/(b−a))∫f(x)dx, motion (displacement=∫v dt, distance=∫|v|dt).

scaffold.title: Review Block B: Mixed Integration Problems

problems.question: Evaluate ∫₀² x√(4−x²) dx.
hints: Try u = 4−x² so that x dx matches part of du.
Don't forget to change the bounds of integration.

problems.question: Solve the IVP: dy/dx = 2xy², y(0) = 1.
problems.answer: Separate: dy/y² = 2x dx. Integrate: −1/y = x² + C. y(0)=1: −1=C. So −1/y = x²−1 → y = 1/(1−x²). Domain: |x| < 1.
hints: Move y² to the left side and dx to the right.
After integrating, use the initial condition to find C.

problems.question: The base of a solid is the region between y = sin(x) and the x-axis for 0 ≤ x ≤ π. Cross-sections perpendicular to the x-axis are semicircles. Set up and evaluate the volume.
problems.answer: Diameter of semicircle = sin(x), so radius = sin(x)/2. A(x) = (1/2)π(sin(x)/2)² = πsin²(x)/8. V = ∫₀^π πsin²(x)/8 dx = (π/8)·∫₀^π (1−cos(2x))/2 dx = (π/16)[x−sin(2x)/2]₀^π = (π/16)(π) = π²/16.
hints: The diameter of each semicircle equals the distance between the curves.
Use the half-angle identity for sin²(x).

scaffold.title: Review Block C: Parametric/Polar/Vectors & Series (Units 9–10, BC-exclusive)
scaffold.content: Review of BC-exclusive content that makes up ~29% of the AP exam.
keyPoints: Parametric: dy/dx = (dy/dt)/(dx/dt); d²y/dx² = (d/dt[dy/dx])/(dx/dt); speed = √((dx/dt)²+(dy/dt)²); arc length = ∫ speed dt.
Polar: A = (1/2)∫r²dθ; dy/dx for polar = (r'sinθ+rcosθ)/(r'cosθ−rsinθ); find intersection angles carefully.
Vector-valued: v(t)=⟨x'(t),y'(t)⟩, a(t)=v'(t), speed=|v(t)|, distance=∫|v|dt, position from velocity: r(t)=r(a)+∫ₐᵗv(s)ds.
Sequences: convergent if limit exists and is finite.
Series: nth-term test (divergence only), geometric (|r|<1), p-series (p>1), comparison, limit comparison, ratio test (factorials!), integral test.
Alternating series: converges if |aₙ| decreasing to 0; error ≤ |first omitted term|; absolute vs conditional convergence.
Taylor/Maclaurin: Pₙ(x)=Σf⁽ᵏ⁾(a)(x−a)ᵏ/k!. MEMORIZE: eˣ=Σxⁿ/n!, sinx=Σ(−1)ⁿx²ⁿ⁺¹/(2n+1)!, cosx=Σ(−1)ⁿx²ⁿ/(2n)!, 1/(1−x)=Σxⁿ.
Power series: ratio test for R, CHECK ENDPOINTS separately. Term-by-term diff/integration preserves R.
Lagrange error: |Rₙ(x)|≤M|x−a|ⁿ⁺¹/(n+1)! where M=max|f⁽ⁿ⁺¹⁾| on interval.

scaffold.title: Review Block C: Mixed BC-Exclusive Problems

problems.question: Find the area enclosed by one loop of r = sin(2θ).
hints: Identify the bounds for one complete petal.
Use the identity sin²(u) = (1−cos(2u))/2.

problems.question: Determine whether Σ_{n=1}^∞ n!/(nⁿ) converges or diverges.
hints: The ratio test is the best tool when factorials are involved.
Recognize (n/(n+1))ⁿ as a form that approaches 1/e.

problems.question: Find the Maclaurin series for f(x) = ∫₀ˣ e^(−t²) dt through the x⁵ term.
problems.answer: e^(−t²) = Σ(−t²)ⁿ/n! = 1 − t² + t⁴/2 − t⁶/6 + ⋯. Integrate term by term: ∫₀ˣ e^(−t²)dt = x − x³/3 + x⁵/10 − x⁷/42 + ⋯. Through x⁵: x − x³/3 + x⁵/10.
hints: Start with the known Maclaurin series for eᵘ, then substitute u = −t².
Integrate term by term — power series can be integrated inside their interval of convergence.

scaffold.title: AP FRQ Walkthrough: Multi-Part Free Response

examples.problem: FRQ Practice: Let f(x) = x³ − 6x² + 9x + 1. (a) Find all critical points and classify using FDT. (b) Find intervals of concavity and inflection points. (c) Find the absolute max and min on [0, 5].

FRQ Practice: A particle moves along the x-axis with velocity v(t) = sin(πt/2) − 1 for t ≥ 0. At t = 0, the particle is at x = 3. (a) Find the acceleration at t = 1. (b) Is the speed increasing or decreasing at t = 1? Justify. (c) Find the position at t = 2.
examples.solution: (a) a(t) = v'(t) = (π/2)cos(πt/2). a(1) = (π/2)cos(π/2) = 0. (b) v(1) = sin(π/2)−1 = 0. At t=1 the particle is at rest (v=0), so the question of speed increasing/decreasing is not applicable at this instant (speed has a minimum of 0). (c) x(2) = 3 + ∫₀² [sin(πt/2)−1] dt = 3 + [−(2/π)cos(πt/2)−t]₀² = 3 + [(−(2/π)cos(π)−2)−(−(2/π)cos(0)−0)] = 3 + [(2/π−2)−(−2/π)] = 3 + 4/π − 2 = 1 + 4/π.

examples.problem: FRQ Practice: The Maclaurin series for f is f(x) = Σ_{n=0}^∞ (−1)ⁿx²ⁿ/(2n)! (this is cos(x)). (a) Write the first four nonzero terms. (b) Use these terms to approximate cos(0.5). (c) Show that the approximation in (b) differs from cos(0.5) by less than 1/720.
examples.solution: (a) 1 − x²/2 + x⁴/24 − x⁶/720. (b) cos(0.5) ≈ 1 − 0.25/2 + 0.0625/24 − 0.015625/720 = 1 − 0.125 + 0.002604 − 0.0000217 ≈ 0.87758. (c) This is an alternating series with decreasing terms. Error ≤ |first omitted term| = (0.5)⁸/8! = 1/40320 · 1/256 = 1/10321920 ≈ 9.7×10⁻⁸. Since 1/10321920 < 1/720, the approximation differs by less than 1/720. ✓
By FTC Part 1: f'(x) = √(x³+1). Answer: (A). Common trap: (C) looks like a derivative of the integrand — students mistakenly apply chain rule to the integrand instead of recognizing FTC.

examples.problem: MC: The series Σ_{n=1}^∞ (−1)ⁿn/(n+1) (A) converges absolutely (B) converges conditionally (C) diverges (D) cannot be determined
examples.solution: Check nth-term: lim n/(n+1) = 1 ≠ 0. By the nth-term test, the series diverges. Answer: (C). The alternating sign does NOT help when the terms don't approach 0.

examples.problem: MC: If dy/dx = y/x and y(1) = 2, then y(e) = ? (A) 2 (B) 2e (C) e² (D) 2/e
examples.solution: Separate: dy/y = dx/x → ln|y| = ln|x| + C → y = Ax. y(1)=2: A=2. y = 2x. y(e) = 2e. Answer: (B).

examples.problem: MC (Calc): The area of the region enclosed by y = x³−2x and y = x is closest to: (A) 1.5 (B) 2.25 (C) 3.08 (D) 5.33
examples.solution: Intersections: x³−2x = x → x³−3x = 0 → x(x²−3) = 0 → x = 0, ±√3. On [−√3, 0]: x³−3x > 0 (top). On [0, √3]: x³−3x < 0 (bottom). By symmetry: A = 2∫₀^{√3}(3x−x³)dx = 2[3x²/2−x⁴/4]₀^{√3} = 2[9/2−9/4] = 2·9/4 = 9/2 = 4.5. Hmm, none match exactly. Let me recheck: area between y=x and y=x³−2x is ∫|x−(x³−2x)|dx = ∫|3x−x³|dx. A = 2∫₀^{√3}(3x−x³)dx = 2[3x²/2−x⁴/4]₀^{√3} = 2(9/2−9/4) = 2(9/4) = 9/2 = 4.5. With calculator this computes directly. Actually if the choices were (A) 2.25, (B) 3.08, (C) 4.50, (D) 5.33, answer is (C). The point: use the calculator to evaluate definite integrals quickly.

examples.problem: MC (Calc): A particle moves with velocity v(t) = ln(t+1)−t for t ≥ 0. At what time t does the particle change direction for the first time?
examples.solution: Change direction when v(t)=0 and changes sign. ln(t+1)−t=0 → ln(t+1)=t. At t=0: ln(1)=0=0 ✓, but check: v'(0)=1/(0+1)−1=0. At t=0: v(0)=0. For small t>0: v'(0)=0, v''(t)=−1/(t+1)², v''(0)=−1<0, so v(t)<0 for t just past 0 (v decreasing from 0). So particle starts at v=0, immediately goes negative. No direction change at t=0. Use calculator: graph ln(t+1)−t; it's 0 at t=0, negative for t>0 (since ln(t+1)<t for all t>0). The particle never changes direction — it moves in one direction. Strategy: use calculator to verify graphically.

examples.problem: MC (Calc): The length of the curve y = x³/² from x = 0 to x = 4 is closest to: (A) 5.0 (B) 7.6 (C) 9.1 (D) 10.5

problems.question: Find the interval of convergence for Σ_{n=1}^∞ (−1)ⁿ(x+2)ⁿ/(n·3ⁿ).
problems.answer: Ratio test: L = |x+2|/3. Converges when |x+2| < 3, i.e., −5 < x < 1. R=3. At x=−5: Σ(−1)ⁿ(−3)ⁿ/(n·3ⁿ) = Σ(−1)ⁿ(−1)ⁿ/n = Σ1/n → diverges (harmonic). At x=1: Σ(−1)ⁿ·3ⁿ/(n·3ⁿ) = Σ(−1)ⁿ/n → converges (alt harmonic). IOC: (−5, 1].
hints: Apply ratio test to find R, then check each endpoint separately.

problems.question: Evaluate ∫ x²/(x−1) dx.
problems.answer: Long division: x²/(x−1) = x + 1 + 1/(x−1). ∫ = x²/2 + x + ln|x−1| + C.
hints: When the degree of the numerator ≥ degree of denominator, do polynomial long division first.

problems.question: A particle moves with velocity v(t) = ⟨e^(−t), 2t−1⟩ and position r(0) = ⟨2, 0⟩. Find the position at t = 1 and the total distance traveled from t = 0 to t = 1.
problems.answer: r(1) = ⟨2, 0⟩ + ∫₀¹⟨e^(−t), 2t−1⟩dt = ⟨2, 0⟩ + ⟨[−e^(−t)]₀¹, [t²−t]₀¹⟩ = ⟨2, 0⟩ + ⟨1−1/e, 0⟩ = ⟨3−1/e, 0⟩. Distance = ∫₀¹√(e^(−2t)+(2t−1)²)dt (requires calculator for numerical evaluation).
hints: Integrate each component of v(t) separately to find position.
Distance traveled uses the speed integral — set it up even if you can't evaluate by hand.

problems.question: Use the Lagrange error bound to determine the degree n of the Taylor polynomial for sin(x) centered at 0 needed to approximate sin(1) with error less than 0.001.
problems.answer: sin(x) = Σ(−1)ᵏx^{2k+1}/(2k+1)!. This is alternating with decreasing terms at x=1. Error ≤ |first omitted term| = 1/(2n+3)!. Need 1/(2n+3)! < 0.001 → (2n+3)! > 1000. 7!=5040>1000. So 2n+3=7→n=2. P₅(x) = x−x³/6+x⁵/120 gives error < 1/5040 < 0.001. ✓
hints: For alternating series, the error is bounded by the first omitted term.
Find the smallest factorial that exceeds 1/0.001 = 1000.

problems.question: Find the area inside both r = sin(θ) and r = cos(θ).
problems.answer: Intersection: sinθ = cosθ → tanθ = 1 → θ = π/4. For 0≤θ≤π/4: sinθ ≤ cosθ (inner = sinθ). For π/4≤θ≤π/2: cosθ ≤ sinθ (inner = cosθ). By symmetry: A = 2·(1/2)∫₀^{π/4}sin²θ dθ = ∫₀^{π/4}(1−cos2θ)/2 dθ = [θ/2−sin2θ/4]₀^{π/4} = π/8−1/4.
hints: Sketch both circles to identify the overlapping region.
Use symmetry — the region is symmetric about θ = π/4.

problems.question: FRQ-style: Let g(x) = ∫₀ˣ f(t) dt where f is the piecewise linear function defined by: f(t) = 2t for 0≤t≤2, f(t) = 4 for 2≤t≤5, f(t) = −2(t−5)+4 for 5≤t≤7. (a) Find g(2), g(5), g(7). (b) On what intervals is g concave up? (c) Find the absolute maximum of g on [0, 7].
problems.answer: (a) g(2) = ∫₀² 2t dt = [t²]₀² = 4. g(5) = 4 + ∫₂⁵ 4 dt = 4 + 12 = 16. g(7) = 16 + ∫₅⁷(−2t+14)dt = 16 + [−t²+14t]₅⁷ = 16 + (−49+98−(−25+70)) = 16 + (49−45) = 20. (b) g''(x) = f'(x). f'(x) = 2 on (0,2), 0 on (2,5), −2 on (5,7). g concave up where f'>0: (0,2). (c) g'(x) = f(x) ≥ 0 on entire [0,7] (f goes from 0 up to 4, stays at 4, then decreases to 0 at t=7). So g is nondecreasing. Abs max at x=7: g(7) = 20.
hints: g'(x) = f(x) by FTC Part 1. g''(x) = f'(x).
Compute g values by finding areas under f (trapezoids and rectangles).

answerKeys.fr-wp3: Cut at x = 40√3/(9+4√3) ≈ 4.35 cm for square.
